question: A 10-year-old Caucasian female with Turner's syndrome underwent an abdominal imaging study and was discovered that the poles of her kidneys were fused inferiorly. Normal ascension of kidney during embryological development would be prevented by which of the following anatomical structures?
prompt:
A 10-year-old Caucasian female with Turner's syndrome underwent an abdominal imaging study and was discovered that the poles of her kidneys were fused inferiorly. Normal ascension of kidney during embryological development would be prevented by which of the following anatomical structures?A)Superior mesenteric artery
B)Inferior mesenteric artery
C)Celiac artery
D)Splenic artery

question:
Open reduction of condylar fracture is strongly indicated in
(Or)
Absolute indication for open reduction in condylar fractures
correct_answer: Lateral displacement of the condyle (or) Lateral fracture dislocation condyle
options: A)Condyle fracture along with body fracture
B)Lateral displacement of the condyle (or) Lateral fracture dislocation condyle
D)Condyle is separated from the stump
prompt:
Open reduction of condylar fracture is strongly indicated in
(Or)
Absolute indication for open reduction in condylar fracturesA)Condyle fracture along with body fracture
B)Lateral displacement of the condyle (or) Lateral fracture dislocation condyle
C)200 angulations
D)Condyle is separated from the stump
output0: Open reduction of condylar fracture is strongly indicated in cases where the condyle is fractured along with the body of the bone. This is because the condyle is a critical component of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ) and must be properly aligned to ensure proper functioning of the joint.
output1: Open reduction of condylar fracture is strongly indicated in cases where there is lateral displacement or lateral fracture dislocation of the condyle, as it can help to improve the alignment of the bone and reduce the risk of complications such as infection or delayed healing.
output2: Open reduction of condylar fracture is strongly indicated in cases where the angulation is greater than 200 degrees. This is because fractures with higher angulations are more likely to have a poor outcome if left untreated, and open reduction is often necessary to achieve proper alignment and reduce the risk of complications.
output3: Open reduction of condylar fracture is strongly indicated in cases where the condyle is separated from the stump. This is because the condyle is a critical structural component of the joint and must be properly aligned and fixed in place to ensure proper function and prevent complications such as degenerative arthritis.

question: Main sensory nerve supply to TMJ is through
prompt:
Main sensory nerve supply to TMJ is throughA)Occipital nerve
B)Auriculotemporal nerve
C)Facial Nerve
D)Nerve to masseter
output0: The main sensory nerve supply to the Temporomandibular Joint (TMJ) is through the Occipital nerve. This nerve provides sensation to the joint and surrounding tissues, allowing the brain to perceive the position and movement of the jaw.
output1: The main sensory nerve supply to the Temporomandibular Joint (TMJ) is through the auriculotemporal nerve. This nerve provides sensation to the joint and surrounding tissues, allowing for proper movement and function.
output2: The Facial Nerve is responsible for the sensory innervation of the Temporomandibular Joint (TMJ). It provides sensory information to the brain about the position and movement of the jaw, which is essential for proper jaw function and pain modulation.
output3: The nerve to masseter is the main sensory nerve supply to the temporomandibular joint (TMJ). This nerve is responsible for providing sensation to the joint and surrounding muscles, allowing for proper movement and function of the TMJ.

question: A 16-year-old female presents to her physician’s office after noticing a round lump in her left breast 2 months ago. She reports that the lump seemed to enlarge and became tender just preceding her last 2 menses. It is otherwise painless, and the patient denies any discharge or skin changes. She has no past medical history but her grandmother, age 72, was just diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast. The patient is an avid softball player at her high school and denies alcohol, smoking, or illicit drug use. On exam, the breasts appear symmetric and normal. A 3-cm round, mobile mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There is slight tenderness to deep palpation of the mass. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy on either side. Which of the following is the most likely outcome of this patient’s condition?
correct_answer: This mass will most likely decrease in size or disappear over time
options: A)This mass will decrease in size if the patient starts oral contraceptives
B)This mass slightly increases this patient’s risk of breast cancer in the future
C)This mass will most likely decrease in size or disappear over time
D)If this mass grows rapidly to greater than 5 cm, radiation and chemotherapy are indicated
prompt:
A 16-year-old female presents to her physician’s office after noticing a round lump in her left breast 2 months ago. She reports that the lump seemed to enlarge and became tender just preceding her last 2 menses. It is otherwise painless, and the patient denies any discharge or skin changes. She has no past medical history but her grandmother, age 72, was just diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast. The patient is an avid softball player at her high school and denies alcohol, smoking, or illicit drug use. On exam, the breasts appear symmetric and normal. A 3-cm round, mobile mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There is slight tenderness to deep palpation of the mass. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy on either side. Which of the following is the most likely outcome of this patient’s condition?A)This mass will decrease in size if the patient starts oral contraceptives
B)This mass slightly increases this patient’s risk of breast cancer in the future
C)This mass will most likely decrease in size or disappear over time
D)If this mass grows rapidly to greater than 5 cm, radiation and chemotherapy are indicated

question: Mid year population is estimated on ?
prompt:
Mid year population is estimated on ?A)1st March
B)1st July
C)1st April
D)15th August
output0: The mid-year population is estimated on 1st March because the population on this date is considered to be the most accurate representation of the population at the midpoint of the school year. This is because the school year typically begins in September or October, and the midpoint of the year is usually around March.
output1: The mid-year population is estimated on 1st July because this date is the middle point of the calendar year. This date is commonly used in many countries to estimate the population for the year.
output2: The mid-year population is estimated on 1st April because this date is considered the beginning of the new academic year in many countries. This date is often used as the reference point for demographic and statistical data.
output3: The mid-year population is estimated on 15th August, as this is the date when the population is most likely to be at its peak. This is because it is the middle of the year and the school year has just started, so the population is likely to be at its highest.
